column1: #Text=Polycrystalline samples of Ba1−xSrxAl2O4 (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) were synthesized using a conventional solid-state reaction.
#Text=BaCO3 (99.9%), SrCO3 (99.9%) and Al2O3 (99.99%) powder were mixed at a molar ratio of 1:1 and calcined at 1200 °C for 10 h and at 1300 °C for 12 h in air with intermediate grinding.
#Text=The obtained powder was pressed into a pellet, sintered at 1450 °C for 48 h and then furnace cooled to room temperature.
#Text=These pellets were stored in a vacuum.
#Text=Single crystals of BaAl2O4 were prepared using a self-flux method in a platinum crucible.
#Text=A mixture of previously synthesized BaAl2O4 and BaCO3 with a molar ratio of 50:17 was heated at 1470 °C for 6 h and then slowly cooled to 1200 °C at a rate of 2 °C/h.
#Text=After furnace cooling to room temperature, colourless transparent crystals with a hexagonal shape and with edges approximately 100 μm in length were mechanically separated from the flux.
#Text=Samples obtained from the flux were stored in a vacuum.
#Text=Powder XRD was performed using Cu-Kα radiation in a temperature range between 100 and 500 K.
#Text=The powder XRD profiles revealed that all of the polycrystalline samples are single-phase samples.
#Text=Single-crystal XRD experiments also revealed that the crystals have the P63 crystal structure at room temperature.
#Text=In situ TEM observations were performed in a temperature range of 100 to 800 K using a double-tilted liquid N2 cooling holder and heating holder in the JEM-2010 TEM system (JEOL, Japan).
#Text=After the desired temperature was reached, all of the diffraction patterns were collected with a time interval of more than 30 min until no changes in the diffraction pattern were observed.
#Text=All of the indices in the XRD profiles and the electron diffraction patterns are based on the P6322 parent phase throughout this paper.
